title: New York City’s Best New Year’s Eve Parties
seo_title: The best New Year's Eve parties in New York City
seo_description: How to find the best New Year's Eve parties in New York City.
preview: Come December 31st, hundreds of thousands of revelers will flock to Times Square to watch the famous Swarovski crystal ball drop. But we prefer these top parties, if only for the open bars.
contents:
Come December 31st, hundreds of thousands of revelers will flock to Times Square to watch the famous Swarovski crystal ball drop. But the crowds, frigid temperatures and long wait hardly seem like the best way to ring in 2016. Instead, we prefer these top parties, if only for the open bars.


Cipriani 42nd Street 

Photo courtesy of @cipriani on Instagram.

The Venue: Italian restaurant empire Cipriani converted a 1920s bank headquarters into one of the city’s grandest event spaces, with marble columns, 65-foot ceilings and, of course, a dance-floor.

The Details: Six hours of open bar, a DJ playing Top 40 standards, and a New Year’s toast with Cipriani’s very own prosecco. General Admission starts at $129.

The VIP Option: Bottle and cocktail service, VIP entry and guaranteed seating, from $199 to $229.

The Dress Code: Cocktail attire.


Capitale 

Photo courtesy of @findthecamel on Instagram.


The Venue: Another former bank, Capitale touts the same high ceilings and impressive Italianate architecture as Cipriani. For the New Year’s Eve party, two ballrooms and three private VIP rooms will be the best spot in SoHo to celebrate.

The Details: Six hours of open bar, with dance tunes from a live DJ and a New Year’s champagne toast. General Admission starts at $99.

The VIP Option: Bottle and cocktail service, VIP entry and guaranteed seating, from $179 - $219.

The Dress Code: Cocktail attire.


Hornblower Cruises

Photo courtesy of @hornblowerny on Instagram.

The Venue: Why spend the New Year on land when you can celebrate by sea? Hornblower cruises operate several luxury yachts from Chelsea, taking them on multi-hour tours around lower Manhattan and out to the Statue of Liberty.

The Details: Four-and-a-half hours of open bar, buffet dinner with tabled seating, DJ’d music and a New Year’s toast, for $200.

The VIP Option: Top-shelf open bar and a six-course, seated dinner on a private higher deck, for $360.

The Dress Code: No dress code required, but it’s New Year’s on a luxury yacht...why not wear the tux?



Gotham Hall 

Photo courtesy of @jesgordon on Instagram.

The Venue: The Herald Square ballroom features original filigree brass doors and an inlaid marble dancefloor. Classical architecture complete with soaring corinthian columns and a stained-glass skylight, this is another former bank headquarters turned party spot.

The Details: Six hours of open bar with a live DJ, from $99.

The VIP Option: Reserved banquet seating with bottle service and access to a private VIP bar in a sectioned-off mezzanine with its own bathroom, for $189.

The Dress Code: Cocktail attire.


Bryant Park Grill

Photo courtesy of @takenbysoraya on Instagram.

The Venue: One of the city’s most beautifully situated restaurants, the two-story Bryant Park Grill is tucked behind the New York Public Library and overlooks Midtown’s largest park. It’s a refined alternative to the mayhem happening a few blocks away in Times Square.

The Details: Six and a half hours of open bar with live DJ and a New Year’s toast, for $89.

The VIP Option: Bottle service at reserved table seating and, best of all, VIP access to the restaurant’s rooftop garden overlooking Bryant Park, for $189.

The Dress Code: Black tie optional.
